solution: First, we combine the fraction on the left to give $\frac{5x-3}{x+3} = \frac{1}{x+3}$.  Then, multiplying both sides by $x+3$ gets rid of the denominators and leaves $5x-3 = 1$.  Adding 3 to both sides gives $5x=4$, so $x = \boxed{\frac{4}{5}}$.
chatgpt_solution:
We begin by subtracting $\dfrac{1}{(x+3)}$ from both sides of the equation: \begin{align*}
\dfrac{5x}{(x+3)} - \dfrac{3}{(x+3)} &= \dfrac{1}{(x+3)} \\
\dfrac{5x}{(x+3)} - \dfrac{3}{(x+3)} - \dfrac{1}{(x+3)} &= \dfrac{1}{(x+3)} - \dfrac{1}{(x+3)} \\
\dfrac{5x}{(x+3)} - \dfrac{3 + 1}{(x+3)} &= 0 \\
\dfrac{5x}{(x+3)} - \dfrac{4}{(x+3)} &= 0.
\end{align*}We can combine the two fractions on the left-hand side to get  \[\frac{5x - 4}{x+3} = 0.\]Since the denominator $(x+3)$ can't be zero, in order for this equation to be true, we must have $5x - 4 = 0.$ From this equation, we have $5x = 4.$ Dividing both sides by 5 gives $x= \boxed{\dfrac{4}{5}}.$
